DOCNAME: CASE OF LIBERTY AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants alleged that in DATE ORG operated an LAW ( “ ETF ” ) at GPE , PERSON , which was built to intercept CARDINAL simultaneous telephone channels coming from GPE to GPE and on to the continent . DATE the applicants claimed that the ORG intercepted all public telecommunications , including telephone , facsimile and e - mail communications , carried on microwave radio between the CARDINAL ORG radio stations ( at FAC and GPE ) , a link which also carried much of GPE ’s telecommunications traffic . During this period the applicant organisations were in regular telephone contact with each other and also providing , inter alia , legal advice to those who sought their assistance . They alleged that many of their communications would have passed between the ORG radio stations referred to above and would thus have been intercepted by the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , having seen a television report on the alleged activities of the ETF , the applicant organisations requested ORG ( “ the ORG ” : see CARDINAL below ) to investigate the lawfulness of any warrants which had been issued in respect of the applicants’ communications between GPE and GPE and GPE . On DATE an official of the ORG confirmed that an investigation would proceed and added :

“ ... I am directed to advise you that the ORG has no way of knowing in advance of an investigation whether a warrant exists in any given case . The ORG investigates all complaints in accordance with section CARDINAL of the [ Interception of Communications Act DATE : ‘ the DATE Act’ , see paragraphs CARDINAL below ] establishing whether a relevant warrant or relevant certificate exists or had existed and , if so , whether there has been any contravention of sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL . If ... the ORG concludes that there has been a contravention of sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL , the ORG may take steps under sections DATE ) , ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) . In any case where there is found to have been no contravention , the ORG is not empowered to disclose whether or not authorised interception has taken place . In such instances , complainants are advised only that there has been no contravention of sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL in relation to a relevant warrant or a relevant certificate . ”

CARDINAL . By a letter dated DATE the ORG confirmed that it had thoroughly investigated the matter and was satisfied that there had been no contravention of sections CARDINAL of the DATE Act in relation to the relevant warrant or certificate .

CARDINAL . By a letter dated DATE the applicants complained to the ORG of an unlawful interception , requesting the prosecution of those responsible . The ORG passed the matter to ORG for investigation . By a letter dated DATE the police explained that no investigation could be completed until the ORG had investigated and that a police investigation might then follow if it could be shown that an unwarranted interception had taken place or if any of the other conditions set out in section CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act had not been met . The applicants pointed out , in their letter of CARDINAL DATE , that the vague , albeit statutory , response of the ORG would mean that they would not know whether a warrant had been issued or , if it had , whether it had been complied with . They would not , therefore , be in a position to make submissions to the police after the ORG investigation as to whether or not a criminal investigation was warranted . The applicants asked if , and if so how , the police could establish for themselves whether or not a warrant had been issued , so as to decide whether an investigation was required , and how the police would investigate , assuming there had been no warrant .

CARDINAL . The ORG responded on DATE that the police had to await the ORG decision , and the police responded on DATE that the applicants’ concerns were receiving the fullest attention , but that they were unable to enter into discussion on matters of internal procedure and inter - departmental investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants wrote to the police pointing out that , having received the decision of the ORG , they still did not know whether or not there had been a warrant or whether there had been unlawful interception . The response , dated DATE , assured the applicants that police officers were making enquires with the relevant agencies with a view to establishing whether there had been a breach of section CARDINAL of the DATE Act and identifying the appropriate investigative authority . The police informed the applicants by a letter dated DATE that their enquiries continued , and , by a letter dated DATE , that these enquiries had not revealed an offence contrary to section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act .
CARDINAL . On DATE the former statutory regime for the interception of communications was replaced by ORG ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) and a new tribunal , the ORG , was created .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants began proceedings in the ORG against the security and intelligence agencies of GPE , complaining of interferences with their rights to privacy for their telephone and other communications from DATE ( NORP - Irish Rights Watch and others v. ORG and others , IPT/CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CH ) . The ORG , sitting as its President and Vice - President ( a ORG and a ORG judge ) , had security clearance and was able to proceed in the light not just of open evidence filed by the defendant services but also confidential evidence , which could not be made public for reasons of national security .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG made a number of preliminary rulings on points of law . Although the applicants had initially formulated a number of claims , by the time of the ruling these had been narrowed down to a single complaint about the lawfulness of the “ filtering process ” , whereby communications between GPE and an external source , captured under a warrant pursuant to LAW ) of LAW ( which had replaced section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act : see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) , were sorted and accessed pursuant to secret selection criteria . The question was , therefore , whether “ the process of filtering intercepted telephone calls made from the GPE to overseas telephones ... breaches LAW [ of LAW ] because it is not ‘ in accordance with the law’ ” .

CARDINAL . The ORG found that the difference between the warrant schemes for interception of internal and external communications was justifiable , because it was more necessary for additional care to be taken with regard to interference with privacy by a Government in relation to domestic telecommunications , given the substantial potential control it exercised in this field ; and also because its knowledge of , and control over , external communications was likely to be much less extensive .
CARDINAL . As to whether the law was sufficiently accessible and foreseeable for the purposes of LAW , the ORG observed :

“ The selection criteria in relation to accessing a large quantity of as yet unexamined material obtained pursuant to a sCARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant ( as indeed in relation to material obtained in relation to a sCARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant ) are those set out in sCARDINAL(CARDINAL ) . The Complainants’ Counsel complains that there is no ‘ publicly stated material indicating that a relevant person is satisfied that the [ accessing ] of a particular individual ’s telephone call is proportionate’ . But the ORG submit that there is indeed such publicly stated material , namely the provisions of sCARDINAL(l ) of LAW which requires a public authority to act compatibly with Convention rights , and thus , it is submitted , imposes a duty to act proportionately in applying to the material the sCARDINAL(CARDINAL ) criteria .

To that duty there is added the existence of CARDINAL safeguards listed by ORG , namely ( CARDINAL ) the criminal prohibition on unlawful interception ( CARDINAL ) the involvement of the Secretary of ORG ( CARDINAL ) the guiding role of ORG ( ‘ JIC’ ) ( CARDINAL ) LAW ( CARDINAL ) the oversight by LAW ( whose powers are set out in Part IV of the Act ) ( CARDINAL ) the availability of proceedings before this Tribunal and ( CARDINAL ) the oversight by ORG , an all - party body of CARDINAL Parliamentarians created by the Intelligence Services Act DATE ...

It is plain that , although in fact the existence of all these safeguards is publicly known , it is not part of the requirements for accessibility or foreseeability that the precise details of those safeguards should be published . ORG has pointed out that it appears from the Respondents’ evidence that there are in existence additional operating procedures , as would be expected given the requirements that there be the extra safeguards required by sCARDINAL of the LAW , and the obligation of the Secretary of ORG to ensure their existence under sCARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) . It is not suggested by the Complainants that the nature of those operating procedures be disclosed , but that their existence , i.e. something along the lines of what is in the Respondents’ evidence , should itself be disclosed in LAW .

We are unpersuaded by this . First , such a statement in DATE , namely as to the existence of such procedures , would in fact take the matter no further than it already stands by virtue of the words of the statute . But in any event , the existence of such procedures is CARDINAL of the substantial number of safeguards which are known to exist . Accessibility and foreseeability are satisfied by the knowledge of the criteria and the knowledge of the existence of those multiple safeguards .

... [ F]oreseeability is only expected to a degree that is reasonable in the circumstances , and the circumstances here are those of national security ... In this case the legislation is adequate and the guidelines are clear . PERSON does not require that a person who telephones abroad knows that his conversation is going to be intercepted because of the existence of a valid s. CARDINAL ) warrant . ...

The provisions , in this case the right to intercept and access material covered by a s.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant , and the criteria by reference to which it is exercised , are in our judgment sufficiently accessible and foreseeable to be in accordance with law . The parameters in which the discretion to conduct interception is carried on , by reference to s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and subject to the safeguards referred to , are plain from the face of the statute . In this difficult and perilous area of national security , taking into account both the necessary narrow approach to Article PERSON ) and the fact that the burden is placed upon the Respondent , we are satisfied that the balance is properly struck . ”

CARDINAL . During the period at issue in this application the relevant legislation was sections CARDINAL of ORG DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) , which came into force on DATE and was repealed by ORG ( “ the CARDINAL Act ” ) .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , a person who intentionally intercepted a communication in the course of its transmission by post or by means of a public telecommunications system was guilty of an offence . A number of exceptions were made , the relevant CARDINAL being a communication intercepted pursuant to a warrant issued by the Secretary of ORG under LAW and in accordance with a certificate issued under section CARDINAL ) of LAW .
CARDINAL . NORP The Secretary of ORG ’s power to issue a warrant under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act could be exercised only if he considered the warrant necessary :
“ ( a ) in the interests of national security ;
( b ) for the purpose of preventing or detecting serious crime ; or
( c ) for the purpose of safeguarding the economic well - being of GPE . ”
CARDINAL . The term “ serious crime ” was defined by section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW as follows :
“ For the purposes of [ the DATE Act ] , conduct which constitutes or , if it took place in GPE , would constitute one or more offences shall be regarded as a serious crime if , and only if –
( a ) it involves the use of violence , results in substantial financial gain or is conduct by a large number of persons in pursuit of a common purpose ; or

( b ) the offence , or one of the offences , is an offence for which a person who has attained the age of CARDINAL and has no previous convictions could reasonably be expected to be sentenced to imprisonment for a term of DATE or more . ”

CARDINAL . The scope of the term “ national security ” was clarified by the Commissioner appointed under LAW . In his DATE report he stated ( § CARDINAL ) that he had adopted the following definition : activities “ which threaten the safety or well - being of the ORG , and which are intended to undermine or overthrow Parliamentary democracy by political , industrial or violent means ” .

CARDINAL . In determining whether a warrant was necessary for CARDINAL of the CARDINAL reasons set out in CARDINAL ) of LAW , the Secretary of ORG was under a duty to take into account whether the information which it was considered necessary to acquire could reasonably be acquired by other means ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . In addition , warrants to safeguard the economic well - being of GPE could not be issued unless the information to be acquired related to the acts or intentions of persons outside GPE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . A warrant required the person to whom it was addressed to intercept , in the course of their transmission by post or by means of a public telecommunications system , such communications as were described in the warrant .
CARDINAL . Two types of warrant were permitted by LAW . The first , a “ section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant ” , was a warrant that required the interception of :

“ ( a ) NORP such communications as are sent to or from one or more addresses specified in the warrant , being an address or addresses likely to be used for the transmission of communications to or from– PERSON ( i ) NORP one particular person specified or described in the warrant ; or PERSON ( ii ) NORP one particular set of LOC so specified or described ; and
( b ) such other communications ( if any ) as it is necessary to intercept in order to intercept communications falling within paragraph ( a ) above . ”

By section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act , the word “ person ” was defined to include any organisation or combination of persons and the word “ address ” was defined to mean any postal or telecommunications address .

CARDINAL . The second type of warrant , a “ section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant ” , was one that required the interception , in the course of transmission by means of a public telecommunications system , of :
“ ( i ) NORP such external communications as are described in the warrant ; and
( ii ) NORP such other communications ( if any ) as it is necessary to intercept in order to intercept such external communications as are so described ... ” .

CARDINAL . When he issued a section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant , the Secretary of ORG was required to issue also a certificate containing a description of the intercepted material the examination of which he considered necessary in the interests of national security , to prevent or detect serious crime or to safeguard the ORG ’s economic well - being ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ) . A section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant could not specify an address in LOC for the purpose of including communications sent to or from that address in the certified material unless-

“ CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( a ) NORP the Secretary of ORG considers that the examination of communications sent to or from that address is necessary for the purpose of preventing or detecting acts of terrorism ; and

( b ) communications sent to or from that address are included in the certified material only in so far as they are sent within such a period , not exceeding DATE , as is specified in the certificate . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrants could be issued only under the hand of the Secretary of ORG or a permitted official of high rank with the written authorisation of the Secretary of ORG . If issued under the hand of the Secretary of ORG , the warrant was valid for DATE ; if by another official , it was valid for DATE . Only the Secretary of ORG could renew a warrant . If the Secretary of ORG considered that a warrant was no longer necessary in the interests of national security , to prevent or detect serious crime or to safeguard the ORG ’s economic well - being , he was under a duty to cancel it ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . The DATE report of the Commissioner for DATE explained the difference between warrants issued under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) :
“ There are a number of differences ... But the essential differences may be summarised as follows :
( i ) Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrants apply only to external telecommunications ;
( ii ) NORP whereas section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrants only apply to communications to or from one particular person ... or one particular set of LOC , ORG ) warrants are not so confined ; but

( iii ) at the time of issuing a Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant the Secretary of ORG is obliged to issue a certificate describing the material which it is desired to intercept ; and which he regards as necessary to examine for any of the purposes set out in LAW ) .

So the authority to intercept granted by the Secretary of ORG under LAW ) is limited not so much by reference to the target , as it is under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , but by reference to the material . It follows that in relation to LAW ) warrants , I have had to consider first , whether the warrant applies to external communications only , and , secondly , whether the certified material satisfies the Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) criteria . ...

There is a further important limitation on LAW ) warrants . I have said that the authority granted by the Secretary of ORG is limited by reference to the material specified in the certificate , rather than the targets named in the warrants . This distinction is further underlined by LAW ) which provides that material specified shall not include the address in GPE for the purpose of including communications sent to or from that address , except in the case of counter - terrorism . So if , for example in a case of subversion ORG wishes to intercept external communications to or from a resident of GPE , he could not do so under a Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant by asking for communications sent to or from his address to be included in the certified material . But it would be possible for ORG to get indirectly , through a legitimate examination of certified material , what it may not get directly . In such cases it has become the practice to apply for a separate warrant under LAW ) known as an overlapping warrant , in addition to the warrant under LAW ) . There is nothing in the [ CARDINAL LAW ] which requires this to be done . But it is obviously a sound practice , and wholly consistent with the legislative intention underlying Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) . Accordingly I would recommend that where it is desired to intercept communications to or from an individual residing in LOC , as a separate target , then in all cases other than counter - terrorism there should be a separate warrant under LAW ) , even though the communications may already be covered by a warrant under LAW ) . The point is not without practical importance . For the definition of “ relevant warrant ” and “ relevant certificate ” in LAW ) of the LAW makes it clear that , while the ORG has power to investigate warrants issued under section CARDINAL ) and certificates under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) where an address is specified in the certificate , it has no such power to investigate LAW ) warrants , where an address is not so certified . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act was entitled “ Safeguards ” and read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Where the Secretary of ORG issues a warrant he shall , unless such arrangements have already been made , make such arrangements as he considers necessary for the purpose of securing-
( a ) that the requirements of subsections ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) below are satisfied in relation to the intercepted material ; and
( b ) where a certificate is issued in relation to the warrant , that so much of the intercepted material as is not certified by the certificate is not read , looked at or listened to by any person .
( CARDINAL ) The requirements of this subsection are satisfied in relation to any intercepted material if each of the following , namely-
( a ) the extent to which the material is disclosed ;
( b ) the number of persons to whom any of the material is disclosed ;
( c ) the extent to which the material is copied ; and
( d ) the number of copies made of any of the material ;
is limited to the minimum that is necessary as mentioned in LAW ) above .

( CARDINAL ) The requirements of this subsection are satisfied in relation to any intercepted material if each copy made of any of that material is destroyed as soon as its retention is no longer necessary as mentioned in LAW ) above . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provided for a ORG to investigate complaints from any person who believed that communications sent by or to him had been intercepted . Its jurisdiction , so far as material , was limited to investigating whether there was or had been a “ relevant warrant ” or a “ relevant certificate ” and , where there was or had been , whether there had been any contravention of sections CARDINAL of the DATE Act in relation to that warrant or certificate . LAW ) read , in so far as relevant , as follows :
“ For the purposes of this section –
( a ) a warrant is a relevant warrant in relation to an applicant if –
( i ) the applicant is specified or described in the warrant ; or
( ii ) an address used for the transmission of communications to or from a set of LOC in GPE where the applicant resides or works is so specified ;

( b ) a certificate is a relevant certificate in relation to an applicant if and to the extent that an address used as mentioned in paragraph ( a)(ii ) above is specified in the certificate for the purpose of including communications sent to or from that address in the certified material . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG applied the principles applicable by a court on an application for judicial review . If it found there had been a contravention of the provisions of the LAW , it was to give notice of that finding to the applicant , make a report to the Prime Minister and to the Commissioner appointed under LAW and , where it thought fit , make an order quashing the relevant warrant , directing the destruction of the material intercepted and/or directing the Secretary of ORG to pay compensation . In other cases , the ORG was to give notice to the applicant stating that there had been no contravention of sections CARDINAL of the Act .

CARDINAL . The ORG consisted of CARDINAL members , each of whom was required to be a qualified lawyer of not DATE standing . They held office for a DATE period and could be re - appointed . The decisions of the ORG were not subject to appeal .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that a Commissioner be appointed by the Prime Minister . He or she was required to be a person who held , or who had held , high judicial office . The Commissioner ’s functions included the following :
– to keep under review the carrying out by the Secretary of ORG of the functions conferred on him by sections CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ;
– to give to the ORG all such assistance as it might require for the purpose of enabling it to carry out its functions ;
– to keep under review the adequacy of the arrangements made under section CARDINAL for safeguarding intercepted material and destroying it where its retention was no longer necessary ;

– to report to the Prime Minister if there appeared to have been a contravention of sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL which had not been reported by the ORG or if the arrangements under LAW were inadequate ;

– to make an DATE report to the Prime Minister on the exercise of the Commissioner ’s functions . This report had to be laid before ORG . The Prime Minister had the power to exclude any matter from the report if publication would have been prejudicial to national security , to the prevention or detection of serious crime or to the well - being of GPE . The report had to state if any matter had been so excluded .
CARDINAL . In his first report as Commissioner , in DATE , Sir PERSON , as he then was , explained his own role as part of the safeguards inherent in the DATE Act as follows :

“ The third major safeguard is provided by the Commissioner himself . While there is nothing to prevent consultation of the Commissioner before a warrant is issued , it is not the practice to consult him in advance and such consultation on a routine basis would not be practicable . So the Commissioner ’s view is largely retrospective , to check that warrants have not been issued in contravention of the LAW and that appropriate procedures were followed . To that end , I have visited all the warrant issuing departments and agencies named in this report , in most cases more than once , and discussed at some length the background to the warrant applications . I have also discussed the procedure for seeking warrants with officials at various levels in all the initiating bodies and presenting departments . I have inspected a significant number of warrants , some chosen by me at random , some put before me because it was felt that I should see them . Although I have described ... a number of instances in which mistakes were made or mishaps occurred , I have seen no case in which the statutory restrictions were deliberately evaded or corners knowingly cut . A salutary practice has grown up by which the Commissioner ’s attention is specifically drawn to any case in which an error or contravention of the LAW has occurred : I accordingly believe that there has been no such case during DATE of which I am unaware . ”
Similar conclusions about the authorities’ compliance with the law were drawn by all the Commissioners in their reports during DATE .

CARDINAL . In each of the DATE reports made under the DATE Act the Commissioner stated that in his view the arrangements made under section DATE were adequate and complied with , without revealing what the arrangements were . In the DATE Report the Commissioner noted at § CARDINAL that there had been technological advances in the telecommunications field which had “ necessitated the making of further arrangements by the Secretary of ORG for the safeguarding of material under section CARDINAL of the [ CARDINAL Act ] ” . The Commissioner stated that he had reviewed the adequacy of the new arrangements . For DATE , the Commissioner recorded that , as a result of a new practice of the police disclosing some material to ORG , a further change in the section CARDINAL arrangements had been required . The Commissioner said in the DATE Report that he was “ satisfied with the adequacy of the new arrangements ” ( DATE Report at § CARDINAL ) . In the DATE Report , the Commissioner stated that there had been some minor changes to the section CARDINAL arrangements and confirmed that he was satisfied with the arrangements as modified ( § CARDINAL of the DATE Report ) . In the DATE Report , the Commissioner said at LAW :

“ Some of the written statements of section CARDINAL safeguards which I inspected required to be updated to take account of changes in the public telecommunications market since they had been drafted and approved . Other statements could , as it seemed to me , be improved by more explicit rules governing the circumstances and manner in which , and the extent to which , intercept material could be copied . It also seemed to me that it would be advantageous , where this was not already done , to remind all involved m handling intercept material on a regular basis of the safeguards to which they were subject , securing written acknowledgements that the safeguards had been read and understood . These suggestions appeared to be readily accepted by the bodies concerned . They did not in my view indicate any failure to comply with section CARDINAL of the LAW . ”
In DATE as Commissioner , Lord PERSON reported the following on this issue of section QUANTITY safeguards ( DATE Report , § CARDINAL ) :

“ Like my predecessors , I have on each of my visits considered and discussed the arrangements made by the Secretary of ORG under section CARDINAL for the purpose of limiting the dissemination and retention of intercepted material to what is necessary within the meaning of LAW . Each agency has its own set of such arrangements , and there are understandable variations between them . For example , the practical considerations involved in deciding what is necessary in the interests of national security , or the economic well - being of GPE ( the areas with which ORG and ORG are almost exclusively concerned ) are somewhat different from those involved in the prevention and detection of serious criminal offences ( with which the police forces and ORG are almost exclusively concerned ) . I am satisfied that all of the agendas are operating within the existing approved safeguards under the terms of the arrangements as they stand ... ”

CARDINAL . The CARDINAL Act came into force on DATE . The explanatory memorandum described the main purpose of the Act as being to ensure that the relevant investigatory powers were used in accordance with human rights . As to the first , interceptions of communications , LAW repealed , inter alia , sections CARDINAL of the DATE Act and provides for a new regime for the interception of communications .

CARDINAL . The CARDINAL Act is designed to cover the purposes for which the relevant investigatory powers may be used , which authorities can use the powers , who should authorise each use of the power , the use that can be made of the material gained , judicial oversight and a means of redress for the individual .

CARDINAL . A new Investigatory Powers Tribunal ( “ IPT ” ) assumed the responsibilities of the former ORG , of ORG and of ORG . The Interception of Communications Commissioner continues to review the actions of the Secretary of ORG as regards warrants and certificates and to review the adequacy of the arrangements made for the execution of those warrants . He is also , as before , to assist the ORG . In addition , the Secretary of ORG is to consult about and to publish codes of practice relating to the exercise and performance of duties in relation to , inter alia , interceptions of communications .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of QUANTITY defines interception as follows :

“ For the purposes of this LAW , but subject to the following provisions of this section , a person intercepts a communication in the course of its transmission by means of a telecommunications system if , and only if , he –
( a ) so modifies or interferes with the system , or its operation ,
( b ) so monitors transmissions made by means of the system , or
( c ) so monitors transmissions made by wireless telegraphy to or from apparatus comprised in the system ,
as to make some of all of the contents of the communication available , while being transmitted , to a person other than the sender or intended recipient of the communication . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of QUANTITY provides that the Secretary of ORG shall not issue an interception warrant unless he believes that the warrant is necessary , inter alia , in the interests of national security , for the purpose of preventing or detecting serious crime or for the purpose of safeguarding the economic well - being of GPE and that the conduct authorised by the warrant is proportionate to what is sought to be achieved by that conduct .

CARDINAL . In addition to the general safeguards specified in section CARDINAL of the LAW , section CARDINAL additional safeguards in the case of certificated warrants ( namely warrants for interception of external communications supported by a certificate ) . In particular , section DATE ) provides that intercepted material is to be read , looked at or listened to by the persons to whom it becomes available by virtue of the warrant to the extent only that it has been certified as material the examination of which is necessary for CARDINAL of the above purposes and falls within subsection ( CARDINAL ) . Intercepted material falls within subsection ( CARDINAL ) so far only as it is selected to be read , looked at or listened to otherwise than according to a factor which is referable to an individual who is known to be for the time being in GPE and has as its purpose , or one of its purposes , the identification of material in communications sent by that person , or intended for him .

CARDINAL . NORP In its Ruling of DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL above ) , the ORG set out the following extracts from ORG issued pursuant to s. CARDINAL of QUANTITY ( “ the Code of Practice ” ) . PERSON ) of the Code of Practice deals with the application for a s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant as follows :
“ An application for a warrant is made to the Secretary of ORG . . . Each application , a copy of which must be retained by the applicant , should contain the following information :
• Background to the operation in question .
• Person or premises to which the application relates ( and how the person or LOC feature in the operation ) .
• Description of the communications to be intercepted , details of communications service provider(s ) and an assessment of the feasibility of the interception operation where this is relevant .
• Description of the conduct to be authorised as considered necessary in order to carry out the interception , where appropriate .
• An explanation of why the interception is considered to be necessary under the provisions of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) .
• A consideration of why the conduct is to be authorised by the warrant is proportionate to what is sought to be achieved by that conduct .

• A consideration of any unusual degree of collateral intrusion and why that intrusion is justified in the circumstances . In particular , where the communications in question might affect religious , medical or journalistic confidentiality or legal privilege , this must be specified in the application .
• Where an application is urgent , supporting justification should be provided .
• An assurance that all material intercepted will be handled in accordance with the safeguards required by LAW .
The ORG continued :
“ Applications for a s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) warrant are addressed in subparagraph CARDINAL of the Code of Practice :
‘ An application for a warrant is made to the Secretary of ORG ... each application , a copy of which must be retained by the applicant , should contain the following information :
• Background to the operation in question [ identical to the first bullet point in CARDINAL ] .
• Description of the communications ... [ this is materially identical to the third bullet point in CARDINAL ] .

• Description of the conduct to be authorised , which must be restricted to the interception of external communications , or to conduct necessary in order to intercept those external communications , where appropriate [ compare the wording of the fourth bullet in CARDINAL ] .
• The certificate that will regulate examination of intercepted material .
• An explanation of why the interception is considered to be necessary for CARDINAL or more of the section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) purposes [ identical to the fifth bullet point in DATE ] .
• A consideration of why the conduct should be authorised by the warrant is proportionate . . . [ identical to the sixth bullet point in DATE ] .
